5.3.1

Parallel Axis Theorem: Parallel Axis Theorem states that

“The moment of inertiaof a body about a given axis is, where the mass of the body is, the moment of inertia of the body about an axis parallel to the centre of mass and parallel to the given axis is, and the distance between the two axes is”.

Prove the above theorem in two parts. In the first part prove that the first moment of a body in space about any plane through the centre of mass of the body is zero. Then in the second part use this result to prove parallel axis theorem.

Part I : assume that the centre of mass of the body is at the origin. Or in other words, with centre of mass at the origin draw coordinate axes. Consider the plane asplane. Then first moment of the body aboutaxis is given by

Since the distance of the plane fromaxis is zero, the numerator of above expression is 0. Hence; that is the first moment of a body in space about any plane through body’s centre of mass is 0.

Consider the vector triple product,

.

Recall the fact that the cross product of two vectors , is a pseudo vector, and the vector triple product is a just a polar vector.

Here, the term ‘a polar vector’ is used to refer a representation of a vector.

Also, use the fact that

the product of two vectors is a pseudo vector,

the product of two pseudo vectors is a pseudo vector,

the product of one vector and a pseudo vector is a vector only.

It follows that

(a)

If A, B, C are all vectors, then clearly, the cross product is a pseudo vector (since, B, and C are vectors, and the product of two vectors is a pseudo vector), and the vector triple product is just a vector (since, A is a vector, and is a pseudo vector, and the product of one vector and a pseudo vector is a vector).

So, when A, B, C are all vectors, the vector triple product is a vector.
